original_title: Sri Lanka’s stocks close on a 16 month high on macroeconomic clarity
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka shares were up at close on Thursday after buying interest was channeled on clarity on debt restructuring, after the market was down on profit taking due to continuous gains, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index was up 0.48 percent or 54.37 points to 11,312.19, this is the highest the market has been since March 02, while S&P SL20 was up 0.12 percent or 3.77 points to 3,277.53.
“Buying interest was seen in blue chip counters and the banking sector, because concerns have been lifted with regard to debt optimization and macroeconomic factors,” an analyst said.

The market generated a turnover of 7.7 billion rupees, this is the highest turnover has been since February 01 2022, majority of the revenue came in from the food, beverage and tobacco sector bringing in 4.8 billion rupees, while the banking sector 837 million rupees and the diversified financials brought in 536 million rupees, while the yearly average stands at 1.7 billion rupees.
The market generated a net foreign inflow of 296 million rupees.
Sri Lanka’s announced domestic debt restructuring plan has avoided adding to the “fragility” of the banking system, World bank Country Director Faris Hadad-Zervos said.
Sri Lanka kept banks, which have already been hit by bad loans and mark-to-market losses out of re-structuring plan.
Gainers during trade were Senkadagala Finance, Hatton National Bank and Hayleys Fabric.

French Presidents Emmanuel Macron will be in Colombo for a few hours and meet President Ranil Wickremesinghe, top government officials said. The debt restructuring will be among the topics to be included during the discussion, one source said.
Japan’s Foreign Minister Hayashi Yoshimasa will arrive in Sri Lanka on July 28 on a two-day official visit, the President’s media office said.
The Minister will have discussions with Sri Lanka Foreign Minister M UM Ali Sabry, the embassy of Japan said. Japan is a key partner in Sri Lanka’s debt re-structuring efforts.
